links.title: Assertive community treatment - Wikipedia
links.description: Assertive community treatment (ACT) is an intensive and highly integrated approach for community mental health service delivery.[1] ACT teams serve individuals with more serious mental illness, with most having a significant thought disorder (e.g., schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder).  In addition to having more severe symptoms, which are further negatively impacted by societal stigma and discrimination, individuals who qualify for ACT ten...

links.title: O'Connor v. Donaldson - Wikipedia
links.description: O'Connor v. Donaldson, 422 U.S. 563 (1975), was a landmark decision in mental health law. The United States Supreme Court ruled that a state cannot constitutionally confine a non-dangerous individual who is capable of surviving safely in freedom by themselves or with the help of willing and responsible family members or friends. Since the trial court jury found, upon ample evidence, that petitioner did so confine respondent, the Supreme Court uph...

links.title: Addington v. Texas - Wikipedia
links.description: Addington v. Texas, 441 U.S. 418 (1979), was a landmark United States Supreme Court case that set the standard for involuntary commitment for treatment by raising  the burden of proof required to commit persons for psychiatric treatment from the usual civil burden of proof of "preponderance of the evidence" to "clear and convincing evidence".[1]

links.title: Homelessness and Mental Illness: A Challenge to Our Society
links.description: What is the prevalence of mental illness among people experiencing homelessness in the U.S.? According to a 2015 assessment by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, 564,708 people were homeless on a given night in the United States. At a minimum, 140,000 or 25 percent of these people were seriously mentally ill, and 250,000 or 45 percent had any mental illness. By comparison, a 2016 study found that 4.2 percent of U.S. adults have...

links.title: ICANN urges adopting DNSSEC now
